bestBHT.bht: In the passage, believers are warned against despising or judging one another based on differences in faith or practices. It is not our place to dismiss others or criticize their choices, as God has accepted them into His family despite these differences. Instead, those with stronger faith are encouraged to show understanding and kindness towards those with weaker faith. This passage reminds us to avoid division and to recognize that all believers are part of God's family.

Henry Alford: Despise, for his weakness of faith,—judge, for his laxity of practice.
For God hath received him (i. e. the eater, who was judged,—his place in God’s family doubted: not the abstainer, who was only despised, set at nought...
And to whom the words cannot, by the construction, apply.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Let not him that eateth despise... him that eateth not."
Let not him that eateth not judge... him that eateth.
God hath received him... who in this matter acts not from laxity, but religious principle.
Albert Barnes: Let not him that eateth...Despise him...Him that eateth not...Judge him...The true direction to be given in such a case is, 'to the one party,' not to treat the scruples of the other with derision and contempt, but with tenderness and indulgence.
If he can be 'reasoned' out of it, it is well; but to attempt to 'laugh' him out of it is unkind, and will tend only to confirm him in his views.

He has a right to 'his' opinion; and while I do not 'despise' him, he has no right to 'judge' me. This is the foundation of true charity; and if this simple rule had been followed, how much strife, and even bloodshed, would it have spared in the church.
Marvin Vincent: Despise [εξουθενειτω] . The verb means literally to throw out as nothing. Rev., better, set at nought.
Judgment is assigned to the weak brother, contempt to the stronger. Censoriousness is the peculiar error of the ascetic, contemptuousness of the liberal.
The weak brother is the biggest bully in the universe! Both extremes are allied to spiritual pride.
John Calvin: When you see a man illuminated with the knowledge of God, you have evidence enough that he is received by the Lord; if you either despise or condemn him, you reject him whom God has embraced.
The weak, the condemner, is the person reproved, and therefore the strong is he who to his own master stands or falls.
The condemner throughout is the weak, and the despised is the strong.
Philip Schaff: The self-consciousness of strength misleads into looking down with contempt on the weak" (Meyer).
The weak brother fails to comprehend the liberty of the stronger one; his misjudgment leads to false judgment" (Commentary).
The strong do not reject, but, while tolerating, are prone to despise the weak" (Commentary).
Archibald T. Robertson: Set at nought (εξουθενειτω)...to treat as nothing and so with contempt.
Received him (αυτον προσελαβετο)...God took both sides into his fellowship without requiring that they be vegetarians or meat-eaters.
John Gill: Such who had a greater degree of Gospel light and knowledge, and made use of their Christian liberty in eating any sort of food, were not to despise as they were apt to do, such as abstained therefrom on account of the ceremonial law...
Leave them to the last and righteous judgment, when every one must be accountable to God for the various actions of life.
God had received both the one and the other into his heart's love and affection, into the covenant of grace, and into his family by adoption.
John Wesley: Despise him that eateth not — As over-scrupulous or superstitious.
Judge him that eateth — As profane, or taking undue liberties.
For God hath received him — Into the number of his children, notwithstanding this.

bhtAttempts.bht: In Romans 14:3, the first-tier commentaries emphasize the importance of not despising or judging others based on their differing beliefs or practices. It is not for us to determine the righteousness or validity of someone's faith or lifestyle choices; only God has the authority to accept or reject them. This verse admonishes those with stronger faith to not look down with contempt on those with weaker faith, but rather to extend tenderness and understanding. Instead of being divisive, we should remember that all believers, regardless of their differences, are received by God into His family.

In the passage, believers are warned against despising or judging one another based on differences in faith or practices. It is not our place to dismiss others or criticize their choices, as God has accepted them into His family despite these differences. Instead, those with stronger faith are encouraged to show understanding and kindness towards those with weaker faith. This passage reminds us to avoid division and to recognize that all believers are part of God's family.

In Romans 14:3, believers are cautioned against despising or judging one another based on differences in faith or practices. Instead, we are reminded that God has accepted both sides into His family, regardless of their choices. The verse calls for understanding and kindness towards those with weaker faith, rather than condemnation. It reminds us that unity is important, and that all believers are part of God's family.

Believers are urged to refrain from despising or judging one another due to differing faith or practices. God embraces both those who partake and those who abstain, considering them as part of His family. This verse emphasizes the need for understanding and compassion towards those with weaker faith, rather than dismissive attitudes. It reminds us that unity is paramount and that all believers are welcomed by God, regardless of their choices.

Believers are encouraged to show respect and understanding towards one another, refraining from despising or judging based on differing faith or practices. This passage highlights the acceptance and love of God towards all, regardless of their choices. It reminds us to embrace unity and extend compassion towards those with weaker faith, rather than harboring disdain. In God's eyes, all believers are cherished and welcomed into His family, regardless of their individual convictions.
